title: Trending: Upcycled Cosmetics, Circular Beauty - Cosmetics & Toiletries
summary: The article discusses the growing market for upcycled cosmetic ingredients, highlighting its sustainability and eco-friendly benefits. Several companies, like Kaffe Bueno and IFF, are using by-products from various industries, like coffee and hummus, to create new cosmetic ingredients. This trend of circular beauty aims to minimize waste and promote environmentally responsible practices in the cosmetics industry.

title: Sustainable side-stream management in Swedish food processing companies using external actors and biogas solutions - Frontiers
summary: This article investigates how food processing companies in Sweden manage their side-streams, which are defined as all flows not considered main products.  The study finds that most companies prefer to partner with external companies for side-stream management, rather than developing and investing in the technology themselves. Biogas solutions are identified as a particularly versatile and multifunctional management option for side-streams, particularly due to their ability to recover nutrients.
likely_naics_codes: ['311111 - Animal Slaughtering and Processing', '311411 - Dairy Product Manufacturing', '311811 - Bakeries and Tortilla Manufacturing', '311911 - Food Manufacturing, Nec']
greenwashing: The article does not provide evidence of greenwashing related to the use of biogas solutions for managing side-streams in food processing companies.

title: Upcycling Initiatives Turn Railway Industry Waste Materials into Creative Products - The Japan News
summary: Japanese railway companies are implementing upcycling initiatives to transform discarded materials like seat covers, overhead wires, and steel rails into new products. These initiatives, driven by a growing focus on circular economy principles, are not only reducing waste but also attracting new customers who appreciate the sustainability and unique stories behind the products. From slippers made from bullet train seat covers to iron kettles crafted from melted-down rails, these upcycled products offer a sustainable solution while fostering a sense of connection to the railway industry.
likely_naics_codes: ['481110 - Passenger Rail Transportation', '481111 - Railroad Passenger Transportation', '336413 - Fabricated Metal Products, Except Cutlery, Hand Tools, and Hardware', '336415 - Fabricated Structural Metal Products']
greenwashing: The article does not describe greenwashing, as the described practices appear to be genuine efforts to reduce waste and create sustainable products.

title: Why the future of sustainable food in India is upcycling - FFOODS Spectrum - nuFFooDS Spectrum
summary: The article highlights the growing trend of 'upcycled food,' which uses food ingredients that would otherwise be wasted, reducing environmental impact and creating new revenue streams. The Upcycled Food Association (UFA) is promoting this concept and certifying upcycled products to prevent food waste. While the global market is embracing upcycled food, India is still catching up, though experts believe it holds immense potential to combat the nation's food waste problem.

title: what design can do reveals the 13 winners of the make it circular challenge - Designboom
summary: The What Design Can Do (WDCD) Make it Circular Challenge has selected 13 finalists who have developed innovative solutions for a more circular economy. These solutions aim to reduce waste, reuse materials, and work with nature. The winning projects will receive €10,000 in funding and access to a development program to help them bring their ideas to life.

title: Tortilla chips category continues to grow - Snack Food & Wholesale Bakery
summary: The tortilla chip category is experiencing significant growth, with consumers seeking unique flavors, healthier options, and sustainable practices.  Companies are responding with innovative products like chickpea tortilla chips, grain-free options, and upcycled ingredients, while also focusing on transparency and responsible sourcing.  The focus on both taste and sustainability is driving the market's expansion.

title: Q&A: Carbonwave expands seaweed emulsifier as demand grows - CosmeticsDesign.com USA
summary: Carbonwave, a Puerto Rico-based company, has secured $5 million in funding to scale up production of its seaweed-based cosmetic emulsifier, SeaBalance 2000. This emulsifier, derived from Sargassum seaweed, is a sustainable and upcycled alternative to traditional petroleum-based emulsifiers, offering a range of benefits for cosmetic and personal care products.  Carbonwave's innovation addresses the environmental concerns associated with Sargassum seaweed blooms, transforming a potential environmental hazard into a valuable resource.

greenwashing: The article does not indicate any instances of greenwashing, presenting SeaBalance 2000 as a genuine and impactful green innovation.

title: Singapore's Confetti Snacks in talks with Walmart and Target as collaboration with Dole and Disney lays on the horizon - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: Confetti, a company that upcycles surplus crops into snacks, is expanding into the US and APAC markets. They are partnering with major retailers like Walmart and Target in the US and collaborating with Dole to create vegan dips. Confetti is also releasing a special line of chips featuring Disney characters with a localized twist, showcasing their commitment to both sustainability and cultural relevance.

title: Tiger breaks beer-making boundaries to keep up with 'sessionable and accessible' drinking trends - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: Tiger Beer, a brand known for its Asian heritage, has launched a new product called Tiger Soju Infused Lager, inspired by the popular Korean alcoholic beverage combination 'somaek.' The new beer comes in two flavors, Gutsy Grape and Cheeky Plum, and is being marketed with the help of K-pop star G-Dragon. Tiger is also committed to bringing unique experiences to its consumers, as seen in their recent 'Tiger Uncage Festival: Twist to the Night' event.
